pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Āḷavī at the Aggāḷava Shrine,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.2: the monks from the group of six went to the silk-makers and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.3: “Please boil a heap of silkworms and give us silk.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.4: We want to make blankets containing silk.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.5: The silk-makers complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.6: “How can the Sakyan monastics come and say
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.8: It’s our misfortune that we must kill many small creatures because of our livelihood and because of our wives and children.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.9: The monks heard the complaints of those silk-makers,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.10: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.11: “How could the monks from the group of six go to silk-makers and say
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.13: After rebuking them in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.14: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.19: “Foolish men, how could you do this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.22: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.23.1: ‘If a monk has a blanket made that contains silk, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.6: it is made by strewing, not by weaving.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.8: If he makes a blanket that contains even one thread of silk, or he has one made, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.9: When he gets the blanket, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.10: The blanket should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.11: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.12: (To be expanded as in Relinquishment 1, with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.13: ‘Venerables, this blanket containing silk, which I got made, is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.14: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.17: ‘I give this blanket back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.1: If he finishes what he began himself, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.2: If he has others finish what he began himself, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.3: If he finishes himself what was begun by others, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.4: If he has others finish what was begun by others, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.5: If he makes one, or has one made, for someone else, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.6: If he gets one that was made by someone else and then uses it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.8: if he makes a canopy, a floor cover, a cloth screen, a mattress, or a pillow;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.10: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.11: The training rule on silk, the first, is finished.
